Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Massachusetts law implies into every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both at common law and pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that G.L. c. 186, § 14 codified tenants’ common-law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, making clear both the existence of a common-law implied covenant and its statutory embodiment. While the case’s main issue is the fault standard under § 14, its background discussion directly affirms that Massachusetts law implies a covenant of quiet enjoyment into residential tenancies at common law and via § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts law implies into every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both at common law and pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes that failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it applies the statutory quiet enjoyment remedy. However, the case does not state that Massachusetts law implies a covenant of quiet enjoyment into every residential tenancy, nor does it discuss the existence of such a covenant at common law as universally implied in all residential leases. It assumes the covenant’s existence and focuses on its breach and the statutory remedy, so it partially aligns with but does not fully establish the broad proposition claimed.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited. … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction…; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–01 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The complete loss of hot water for an extended period constitutes a serious and substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of a residential dwelling unit, and renders the conditions at the Premises unsafe and in violation of the State Sanitary Code.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats loss of heat and hot water as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and as violations of the State Sanitary Code, but it does not specifically characterize a complete loss of hot water for an extended period—standing alone—as rendering the premises unsafe or as a serious and substantial interference with use and enjoyment. The facts and holding address intermittent heat and hot water problems together and focus on rent abatement and strict liability under the warranty, not on defining the severity of hot water loss in isolation. Thus the case is related but does not directly establish the precise proposition claimed.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The complete loss of hot water for an extended period constitutes a serious and substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of a residential dwelling unit, and renders the conditions at the Premises unsafe and in violation of the State Sanitary Code.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurring/dissenting opinion discussing broad doctrinal questions about implied warranty and the State Sanitary Code; it does not address hot water or any specific condition like a complete loss of hot water. There is no holding here that such a loss constitutes a serious and substantial interference, renders a unit unsafe, or violates the State Sanitary Code. Thus, this citation does not support the precise proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code… fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.” (363 Mass. at 207–208)

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that conditions which violate the State Sanitary Code and materially impact the habitability of an apartment can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly ties liability under G.L. c. 186, §14 to the landlord’s violation of its duty to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions in conformity with the State Sanitary Code, including a requirement that apartments be watertight. It ultimately holds Gem liable under §14 because it violated that sanitary duty and thereby allowed repeated unsanitary flooding that interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This squarely supports the proposition that State Sanitary Code violations materially affecting habitability can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under §14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt:
“Further, a section of the State Sanitary Code (received in evidence), provides that apartments must be watertight… In light of our decisions holding landlords responsible for injuries resulting from breaches of sanitary code provisions, Gem’s behavior was a sufficiently ‘proximate’ cause to justify the imposition of liability…
…The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey… Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway… Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that conditions which violate the State Sanitary Code and materially impact the habitability of an apartment can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does address G.L. c. 186, § 14 and what can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of criminal/drug activity and lack of security measures in common areas, not State Sanitary Code violations or physical habitability defects. The court actually limits the warranty of habitability to physical conditions and does not state that sanitary code–related habitability problems are what give rise to the § 14 claim here. Thus, this opinion does not stand for the specific proposition that sanitary code violations materially impairing habitability constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment under § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. ... We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful activity and to determine the seriousness or substantiality of the interference with the tenancies.

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 310–11 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: A residential tenant’s right to hot water is a basic necessity required for decent, safe, and sanitary housing under state law, and the absence of hot water is recognized as a substantial defect affecting habitability.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the implied warranty of habitability, State Sanitary Code violations, and the measure of damages, but it does not mention hot water or characterize hot water as a basic necessity. Nor does it specifically identify the absence of hot water as a substantial defect affecting habitability. The case is about how to calculate damages for code violations generally, so using it to support a specific proposition about hot water overstates what the opinion actually holds.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt: "We also agree with the judge that McKenna is not entitled to receive damages for the minor code violations in this case. As we emphasized in our earlier opinion, not every defect gives rise to a diminution in rental value, and it has been held that isolated violations may be found not to constitute a breach of the warranty of habitability... In all cases, however, the trial court is given broad discretion to determine whether defects constitute material breaches of the warranty of habitability."

McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.raw_text: McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Mass. 300, 303–04 (1999)
McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to timely restore hot water after notice is not excused by the alleged delay of a supplier or the backorder of a part, as Defendant remains responsible under Massachusetts law for maintaining essential services.
McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address restoration of hot water, delays due to suppliers, or backordered parts, nor does it discuss excuses for failure to maintain essential services after notice. McAllister concerns snow and ice removal, negligence, quiet enjoyment, and implied warranty of habitability, and concludes that natural accumulation of snow and ice is not a habitability defect. It therefore cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about responsibility for timely restoration of hot water despite supplier delays.
McAllister v. Boston Hous. Auth., 429 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The implied warranty of habitability ‘is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises’ (emphasis in original). Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282 (1994). Not every breach of the State sanitary code supports a claim under the implied warranty of habitability. Rather, the implied warranty of habitability applies to significant defects in the property itself... The natural accumulation of snow and ice is not such a defect."

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: Defendant’s conduct and inaction, in the face of known, ongoing violations of the State Sanitary Code affecting essential services, constitutes at least negligent, if not willful, conduct that has interfered with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The proposition is about a landlord’s negligent or willful inaction in the face of known State Sanitary Code violations affecting essential services; Blackett v. Olanoff concerns noise from a lounge the landlords introduced and controlled, not sanitary code or essential services. The case does support the broader principle that a landlord’s conduct or failure to act, where he has control over the source of the interference, can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment even without intent. But it does not involve, or speak in terms of, ongoing sanitary code violations or essential services, so it is not an accurate, on‑point citation for that specific proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. … Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and is liable for damages where such interference is caused by any act or omission.
